31.text:
coming to you this week from the IWA gun trade
show in Nuremberg.

38.text:
A boar bonanza, the blade trade, a rifle so
expensive it's being guarded by gladiators,

43.text:
Chinese water deer, rifle scopes, foxes and
so much more.

71.text: First, Europe's addiction with wild boar.

82.text:
This footage was playing on big screens and
it was the talk of the show. A German princeling,

87.text:
practically a professional boar hunter, stopped
seven animals in their tracks. It may not

93.text:
sit well with some people, but his marksmanship
cannot be questioned.

98.text:
The film has gone viral on YouTube and sales
of Aimpoint scopes and Sauer rifles have soared

105.text:
as a result. The drive takes place in Hungary
where the producers can guarantee the volume

112.text: How long did it take you to film this?

116.text:
This was filmed in different locations but
in general I would say seven-to-eight days

121.text:
And what sort of size wild boar days were
they? It looks like you were shooting a lot

126.text:
Yes, we were shooting quite a big bag there,
but it is quite normal in Hungary because

131.text:
you have huge areas with a large population
of only wild boar and other areas for red

137.text:
deer and other areas for fallow deer and so
on. So we were focusing on the wild boar here

142.text:
So what would be a typical day if you were
a gun in Hungary? How many might you see how

149.text: Per person or by the group?

151.text:
Per person, if you were lucky you would minimum
shoot one, then you have a good day, but then

156.text:
you could shoot up to 10 wild boar in a day,
depends on how skilled you are and how well

162.text:
trained you are, because they will come in
a group you can manage to shoot maybe two

166.text:
or three out of a group if you are very skilled
and then there are the exceptional shooters

170.text:
like Franz Albrecht who is in the movie who
can shoot up to 10 in a group, that is top

176.text:
end. Normal hunters should be able to shoot
one-to-three in an average day.

179.text: What was your best day while you were filming?

182.text:
I shot during that day 17 wild boar on four
different beats so that was a good day.

190.text:
Every European gun manufacturer worth its
salt makes rifles for boar, but they also

195.text:
makes shotguns for pheasants. I asked the
question: pheasant or boar?

201.text:
Now you make both rifles and shotguns, you
like both sports, but if you had to choose

207.text:
one, bird shooting or wild boar, which would
it be?

210.text: I would go for the wild boar shooting.

There is a gun for every occasion at IWA,

and a 20-bore on the other so you don't have
to go home between your grouse and your red

stag. It costs GBP30,000. There's a rather
more expensive gun on this stand that requires

So, OK, this is a fairly expensive rifle.

Yes, that's right, that's the most expensive

Now I want to have a look at a bit on the

We have a programme in the UK called the Antiques

Well it's a calibre .375 Holland and Holland.
You could use it for hunting purposes in Africa

342.text:
as well as in Germany or any other place in

So these are the new range of hunting rifles
from Anschuetz, the target specialists. Now,

351.text:
if you have wild boar and you want to keep

356.text: between Fatal Attraction and Just Juice.

360.text:
Well what we have done in the States is, we
have pigs as well, we have created in the

363.text:
States attractants, apple attractant, corn
attractant, they love corn, we feed them corn,

369.text:
also grape which is our Swine Wine, the grape,
and it actually smells really pungent of grape

376.text:
as the Apple Smash smells like a bushel of
apples times 10. And what it does is it attracts

383.text:
the pigs. A pig's nose is very sensitive and
they smell very much. So whenever they are

390.text:
foraging they smell the apple or the corn
or the swine wine, the grape and they will

396.text: How are you judging the success of the attractant?

399.text:
In Florida, for example, a lot of game farms
there have corn feeders for their deer, their

406.text:
turkey and of course the pigs are there. They
have problems with the 400lb pigs coming in

411.text:
and knocking the corn feeders down so they
really like the grape down there believe it

415.text:
or not. So they dig a hole outside the corn
feeder and put the grape on it and the big

421.text:
pigs will start smelling that and beat all
the little ones off so they'll start killing

425.text:
all the big ones which are knocking the corn
feeders over. We have got story after story

429.text:
like that. So judging it is the fact that
just using it and seeing that it works. Whenever

433.text:
you pour this stuff on the ground in the dirt
you come back a month later and there is a

437.text:
hole in the dirt that big and there are pigs
everywhere that means it works.

From gladiators getting stuffed in the Coliseum

A Somerset dairy farmer who spoke out in support
of the badger cull has condemned animal rights

566.text:
campaigners whom he accuses of poisoning his
milk and burning down his barns. Stuart Thomas's

573.text:
herd tested positive to bovine TB for the
first time in February prompting him to speak

579.text:
out to his local newspaper in support of the
pilot badger culls. Within days, he believes

584.text:
animal activists started targeting his farm.
While police say there does not appear to

588.text:
be a link at this stage they call the offences
extremely serious.

And finally you know when you have made it
when you get your own mug. Adam Stead and

want us to fix it for them to meet the great

You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain

I had the chance, I was stalking in the UK

That's what you wait for because people love

818.text:
After everyone has had a chance to play with
a shiny new optics on the range near Zeiss

823.text:
pro stalker Paul Childerley's stalking ground,
we head off with Ralph and Paul to see whether

829.text: we can get a Chinese buck before dark.

832.text:
We stalk through a number of areas, working
through woodland and open fields. On several

838.text:
occasions Paul tells Ralph to get ready on
the sticks. This Chinese water deer is in

844.text:
thick cover and successfully avoids the cross
hairs. In the denser woodlands we make out

850.text:
shadows, but we want to hold off for a good
buck. Paul brings out the Buttolo call to

856.text:
see what it will deliver. It worked like a
dream this morning. An inquisitive doe shows

862.text:
herself and stands her ground just 20 yards
from us. It really is a wonderful moment when

869.text: you can stop, keep still and stare.

873.text:
This is all very well, but where is our Chinese
water deer buck. Paul suggests settling in

879.text:
a high seat for half an hour, this delivers
nothing so with light fading fast it's back

885.text:
to the open fields which is where Ralph spots
a buck. The camera has no chance, but Ralph

894.text:
takes an excellent shot. Paul is happy with
the result.

899.text:
Well done Ralph. This is a gold medal Chinese
similar to the one you shot before. Good shot

907.text:
taken just on the edge of darkness which is
ideal really just to catch him just before

915.text: he went out of reach. Good shot, well done.

920.text:
Thank you. Well done. We worked hard for this
today.

923.text:
With no lights you saw nothing but through
binoculars and rifle scope it was bright.

930.text:
It was a very nice hunt and you see our two
prototypes did a fantastic job. The brightest

936.text:
binocular, the brightest rifle scope. That
is the proof.

940.text: So you knew it was a gold medal did you?

945.text:
It couldn't have gone better for Ralph, and
Paul and the new Zeiss Victory HT range.

951.text:
A vital piece of kit that occupies thousands
of square feet here is the humble knife. Sporting

958.text:
Rifle editor Peter Carr spots a new range
that really cuts the mustard.

963.text:
Hi Bill. So, what's behind the innovation
for this range?

967.text:
That's a great question Pete. A couple years
ago we went out and followed a bunch of hunters,

971.text:
young athletic hunters and asked them what
is the perfect knife, what would be the perfect

975.text:
product in the field so we went with three
different guide surfaces and watched them

981.text:
what they did, and then designed something
that we thought was very creative and innovative

985.text:
in the market place, something really different
and new. So we went with the mid line. First

990.text:
we go with the Myth Fixed Blade Pro, gut hook,
gripping handle, full tang, so it's a balanced

999.text:
product in your hand. Feel this. One thing
we saw in the field was that they were always

1006.text:
sharpening their knives, separate sharpener
and the knife, so we introduced a new sharpening

1012.text:
method so that every sheath had a sharpener,
carbide, 30 degrees - fantastic, wonderful

1019.text: very quick, job to get done.

1024.text:
It's clear that there's been some hunting
kind of input to this, so you've obviously

1031.text:
We've followed them a lot, we went back to
them many times about size, shape, balance.

1036.text:
Three or four times we went out and dialled
it in to get the best knife for the hunter.

1041.text:
It certainly caught my eye when Kevin showed
me round originally.

1046.text:
That's what was surprising, because a lot
of the guys use small knives. They don't want

1050.text:
to carry large knives out there, so we made
like a peeling knife in the kitchen, full

1055.text:
tang, flexible very flexible blade so it doesn't
break.

1059.text: Even enough flex in there for filleting.

1063.text:
What I liked for a general field knife for
paunching rabbits, breasting pigeons and when

1071.text:
it is buddied up with a gut hook knife on
a field combo it's absolutely perfect for

1075.text:
taking out the backside of a deer and the
length for even gralloching the deer is absolutely

1081.text:
perfect. So it was clear to me that there
was some thinking from a hunting perspective

1087.text:
So, Peter, we took the small blade with the
gut hook blade and combined it with a piggy

1094.text:
back sheath and said hey look you can carry
this one product, your sharpener, your two

1098.text:
knives, you can do anything from caping to
gutting to field dressing. You can do anything

1102.text:
you want with one unit and it stays sharp.
Absolutely fantastic.

1107.text:
And the field dress piggy back number here.
The retail price for this in the UK?

1112.text: I understand it is GBP99 in the UK.

The main aim of this evening is to try and

1312.text:

as soon as we see something, then I will load

1347.text:

But there is doubt in the ranks about the

This is a pretty good shot. Now the guys won't

1386.text:
agree on that? 25 yards? 25 yards is about

out there trying to pick out their eyes, I've

1398.text:
unloaded, bolt open, and I've been able to

1403.text:
actually quite a few rabbits out there, but
they seem to be shot pretty hard so as soon

1408.text:
as they hear the engine or feel the vehicle
coming along the ground, they are heading

1412.text:
for the hills. Yhey are gone so, luckily,
I could see their eyes, I could see where

1416.text:

1423.text: go. So far, the NiteSite is proving invaluable.
